content.description: Climb the concave face full of jugs and dozens of options for holds just right of the knife blade arete of Rump Roast.
content.location: On the South side of the upper Saddle Boulder.

content.description: Sit start and pull on with a weird side-pull pinch and a sloping left hand. Bump left for a long reach to a good square cut edge and top out.
content.location: Center of southeast face of the Rump Roast Boulder. Just left of Peace Keeper.

content.description:
This route even though it quickly becomes easy after the first few moves is aesthetic as they come and almost a mandatory climb while at the Saddle boulders.

On the upper saddle boulder you'll find an obvious knife blade arete. Sit start and make a couple V1ish moves then climb the awesome knife blade arete to the top.
content.protection: Pads, don't fall after you pull over the bulge and are on the arete as you will bounce off it.
content.location: On the west side of the upper Saddle Boulder.

content.description: This is a right to left traverse of one face (the generally south facing side of the boulder that looks out on the town of Vacaville) of the Upper Saddle Boulder. When I've done it I top out on the left side of the face. This is a great problem... if you avoid the large, flat jug just past the halfway point of the traverse, the difficulty is probably more like V3 or V4.
content.location: On the Upper Saddle Boulder. Start on the right arÃªte of the face that looks down at the town of Vacaville (more or less the south face), or start just around the corner. You can top out on the left side of the face or probably just head around the corner. If topping out, the down climb is easy and obvious.

content.description:
Route is located on the north side (facing downhill) of the Upper Saddle Boulder. Start on the left side of the face and traverse to the right, staying low. The crux is moving up from a large pinch to the "Big Horn" located on the knife edge arete(Rump Roast). Moving up onto the north face early makes this problem an easy V2.

It is easily the best climb in the saddle boulder. Loads of heel hooks in the beginning section with bad food holds below the shelf, and becomes more over hang when at crux move to the Big Horn, then ease off on the arete.

Problem is in the shade all day!
content.location: Upper Saddle boulder (the one that is uphill). Route is located on the north facing side of the boulder. It starts on the left side of the north face, and traverses to the right then up the arete.

content.description: Lay-down start extension to Passage. Honestly, it's pretty stupid and desperate, but if you're out of stuff to do on this boulder or are trying to kill time waiting to get on Y crack, maybe consider giving it a try. Start on the ledges just right of the lowest part of the east side of the boulder (~10 feet left of the main start for Passage). Lie down, throw some heels, look for hidden feet under the lip, and fight off the dab while pulling through/traversing/awkwardly humping up the whole lip and ending on Passage as you normally would. Might benefit from being dug out and cleaned off a little more, but it'll go in its current condition. Recommend not padding the start. Best done while actively questioning why you picked up bouldering as a hobby in the first place.
content.protection: Pads if you like, not required though.

content.description: Start on the Right side of the South face and traverse left through quickly diminishing jugs and onto some desperate razor sharp crimps. Pull around the arete and continue along the vertical face until the boulder runs out. Always stay low and off the top holds of the boulder.
content.location: This boulder is located on top of the hill East of the main two Saddle Boulders. From the Saddle Boulders (Y Crack Boulders) follow the trail east up hill along the barbed wire fence. Continue to the top of the hill and the boulder will be strait ahead overlooking the Boxcar Woody boulders.
